awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Causes and Consequences of the Gradients in the Vertical Plasma Drift in the Equatorial Plasma Drift Vortex
awd_abstract_narration:
At low latitudes during the evening twilight period, as the E-region plasma recombines due to fast chemistry, a strong vertical gradient in the plasma density will appear below the F-region peak height. This vertical drift gradient in altitude below the F peak can be surprising large, dynamic, and variable from day-to-day. This award would apply a physics-based model of the ionosphere-thermosphere-electric field to study the relationship between the development of these vertical gradients and a possible production of plasma bubble structure.  In these circumstances the phenomenon of unstable plasma fluids that occur whenever a dense fluid overlies a light fluid will generate strange three-dimensional structures. These plasma depletion regions (often called "bubbles") affect severely communications of radio waves that normally are reflected off the smooth bottom side of the F-region plasma layer. The data that would be used in this study are derived from observations by the Jicamarca Radio Observatory and by the Low Latitude Ionosphere Sensor Network (LISN) network of total electron content and ionosonde measurements of plasma density throughout South America.  Also associated with LISN data are equatorial magnetometer measurements that can be interpreted to produce estimates of upward vertical plasma drift rates during the evening period. These results would be used to explore the day-to-day variability of the gradients to help develop a better understanding of the relationship between the rate of vertical drift and the onset of equatorial plasma bubble production. UTD will be utilizing a graduate student to accomplish much of the data analysis and modeling.

Large equatorial plasma bubbles (EPBs), which are associated with the strongest signal scintillations, have negative impacts on communication and navigation technologies. Society has become dependent on these technologies to accomplish common tasks in transportation services, industrial ventures, and military operations. In addition to addressing these important science questions for the mitigation of negative impacts of F-region plasma structures, these activities will continue and expand multinational collaborations associated with the LISN Project and the JRO.

por.por_cntn:
The project goals were to study the dynamics of the low-latitude ionosphere and the consequences of this process in making the plasma unstable for the formation of small-scale plasma structures that affect communication and navigation signals. This study made it possible to study wave-type structures that travel in the ionosphere, named traveling ionospheric disturbances that can initiate plasma instabilities at low latitudes. It was found that these disturbances typically create electric fields that form mirror images in the opposite hemisphere.  It was also found the general velocity, scale size, periodicity, and the occurrence pattern of these disturbances. Another study examined the consistency of the empirical models of low-latitude plasma drifts and neutral winds. This investigation compared the experimental ion drifts with the velocities produced by a numerical model of the low-latitude electrodynamics driven by a commonly used model of the neutral wind: the Horizontal Wind Model. The project also enables other studies on the total electron content statistics and its relationship with several geophysical parameters that influence its evolution. We applied regression analysis and artificial intelligence algorithms to unravel the total electron content's dependencies on several solar, magnetosphere, and ionosphere parameters. This project had significant societal benefits because it provided information on the role of other processes that are significant for initiating the plasma structures and provided a method to follow them across the South American continent.
